content: Loving read and waxing overly passionately about the physicality of the book are, of course, two different things. I do love to read. It’s my profession. The truth is, fewer than 25% of the population (and I think it is much lower than that) read a book in the last 12 months. A book. On anything. (Not just a novel — hey, there are lots of folks that don’t do novels, and I like some nonfiction myself, so I get that.) I do disagree that “reading” isn’t a moral good. Maybe in an absolute sense it is value neutral, but literacy is necessary to survive. All kinds of literacy, but certainly the basic ability to read. Being a good citizen means at least trying to be informed about things. If one is not informed, if one is wrongly informed, then one may well be doing more damage that not. So I do think reading is a moral good. Or at least a civic good. On the other hand, people who wax poetic about books and paper and how great ludditeness is, yeah, that’s annoying. I do love old books, but hey, I’m a medievalist, so I think manuscripts are awesome! But I also don’t wax poetic about them. (Except when I’m talking to my classes, but that doesn’t count.) I couldn’t, today, deal with someone who wasn’t engaged at all in the world. And you can’t be engaged — really engaged — if you don’t read at all.
